Award.AwardTitle: Analytical Microscopy Methods for Characterizing Lipid Vesicles and Bilayers
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Chemical Measurement and Imaging (CMI) and Chemistry of Life Processes (CLP) programs of the Division of Chemistry support Prof. Joel M. Harris of the University of Utah to develop new approaches to characterizing the composition, structure, and functioning of lipid vesicles and their bilayer membranes. Optical trapping confocal Raman microscopy is being developed to probe the composition and structure of individual lipid vesicles, with an aim to better understand the relationship between the structure of the lipid bilayer and its permeability. This in turn may provide control over molecular uptake and release, which impact drug delivery and trace analysis applications. Fluores¬cence microscopy tools are being developed to probe individual lipid vesicles immobilized on glass surfaces, with an aim of assessing internal pH and molecular transport rates, which can be detected as single-molecule events. The work also seeks to devise means to measure the affiliation of small peptides with supported lipid bilayers, and quantitative determina¬tion of membrane-bound peptide populations and their kinetics of binding and unbinding.

This research will provide routes to new understanding of the structure and functioning of lipid membranes and the processes that affect them. These membranes are important components of living cells, and their understanding is critical, for example, to the successful development of membrane-active pharmaceutical products. The research provides multidisciplinary training of graduate and undergraduate students in spectro¬scopy, microscopy, colloid science, and biological chemistry. The project impacts K-12 education and public awareness through involvement in classrooms, contributions to a new science center serving the metropolitan Salt Lake City area, and new touring exhibits that are transported to rural districts of the State of Utah.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Phospholipid vesicles (spherical structures with a cell-like lipid membrane) have attracted scientific interest as models for biological cells, as delivery vehicles for drugs, as additives in chemical separations, as biocompatible sensing materials, and as containers for studying chemical reactions in small volumes. Despite the importance of lipid vesicles in these applications, characterizing the structure and functioning of lipid vesicles is a challenging task. Similarly, lipid bilayers supported on glass are used as models for cell membranes and for biosensors; however, their characterization requires selective probing of the lipid bilayer/solution interface and high sensitivity detection of the small number of molecules that reside within them. The ability of lipid bilayers to bind or transport molecules depends on the molecular structure and organization of their membranes; thus, measurements are needed that are informative of lipid bilayer composition and structure as well as their interactions with membrane-active molecules.

The major goals of this project have been to develop novel quantitative analysis methods to characterize the composition and structure of lipid vesicles and membranes and to measure transport and binding rates that are critical to their functioning.  To meet these goals, we have successfully developed a novel combination of Raman microscopy (which reports the characteristic vibrations of molecules) and optical-trapping or laser tweezers, where a focused laser beam traps a lipid vesicle for analysis.  We applied this combination to study the composition and membrane structure of individual lipid vesicles. We were able to measure the rates of molecular transport through the membrane and follow chemical reactions both in the membrane and within the vesicle interior. The relationship between the structure of lipid bilayer and its permeability was studied to gain control over the release of the contents of a vesicle, a technique that is useful in drug delivery. The uptake of molecules by a vesicle was harnessed for trace analysis applications. Fluorescence imaging microscopy was developed to examine individual lipid vesicles immobilized on glass surfaces in order to characterize their internal composition and its relationship to uptake of drugs or target analytes.  Imaging of individual molecules was employed to determine the affiliation of small signaling peptides with supported lipid bilayers. This methodology allows quantitative determination of membrane-bound peptide populations and their kinetics of binding and unbinding.  This information is critical to the development and assessment of new pharaceuticals based on peptides that govern cell functions.

The research has been carried out by 5 graduate students, 3 undergraduate students, and a postdoctoral associate. These trainees are educated in cutting-edge methods research in analytical chemistry and microscopy as a part of their degree requirements and professional education. Graduate students and the postdoc also develop skills in mentoring of undergraduate members of the research group.  This research has also had broader impact in the development of two new microscopy techniques, which are being utilized in collaborative research with other labs, in areas unrelated to the goals of this project.
